questions.text: An 8-year-old boy was brought for psychiatric evaluation for intellectual disability. On examination, his IQ was 45. He has a long face, large ears, and macroorchidism. What is the trinucleotide repeat mutation associated with this syndrome?
questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette is suggestive of Fragile X syndrome. The specific trinucleotide repeat sequence in Fragile X syndrome is CGG.

Fragile X syndrome is the most common genetic cause of intellectual disability after Down's syndrome. It is due to the mutation in the familial mental retardation 1 gene (FMR1) located on the long arm of the X chromosome. When cells are cultured in a folate-deficient medium, the cytogenetic alteration was observed as a breach in the staining on the long arm of chromosome X. Since the chromosome appears as broken, it is termed fragile X.

It is associated with the phenomenon of anticipation, where the disease phenotype worsens over generations within a family. The affected males are intellectually disabled, with an IQ in the range of 20 to 60. Neuropsychiatric features include aggressive behaviour, autism spectrum disorder, epilepsy, and anxiety/hyperactivity disorders.

The characteristic phenotypic features include the following:

  • Long face with a large mandible
  • Large everted ears
  • Macro-orchidism (large testicles)
  • Hyperextensible joints
  • High-arched palate
  • Mitral valve prolapse

The given image shows the facial features of Fragile X syndrome.

Other options:

Option B: GAA is the trinucleotide repeat sequence present in Friedreich ataxia.

Option C: CAG is the trinucleotide repeat sequence present in Huntington’s disease, spinocerebellar ataxia 1,2,3,6,7 and spinobulbar muscular atrophy.

Option D: CTG is the trinucleotide repeat sequence present in myotonic dystrophy.

questions.text: A patient presented with reduced levels of high-density lipoprotein, and ABCA1 mutation. On examination, tonsils appeared as shown in the image. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis in this case with reduced levels of high-density lipoprotein (HDL), ABCA1 mutation, and orange tonsils on examination is Tangier's disease. It is caused by a defect in ABCA1 receptors.

ABCA1 plays a role in the efflux of cholesterol from peripheral cells of HDL. LCAT (lecithin cholesterol acyltransferase) converts cholesterol to cholesterol esters, which accumulate in the core of HDL. Thus, defective ABCA1 will lead to low levels of HDL in the blood. 

Other options:

Option B: Abetalipoproteinemia is a hypolipoproteinemia caused by a defect in the MTP gene. Here, loading apolipoprotein B with lipids is defective. Hence, few very low density-lipoproteins (VLDLs) or chylomicrons are formed, leading to the accumulation of triacylglycerols in the liver and intestine.

Option C: Hyperlipoproteinemia is a disorder that causes the body to metabolize lipids incorrectly. This results in hyperlipidemia and can lead to the development of multiple small xanthomas in the skin.

Option D: Acid lipase deficiency can lead to Wolman's disease which is a lysosomal storage disease. The pathognomic feature of this condition is adrenal calcification. So patients generally present with adrenal insufficiency and are neonates.

Related Pearl: Familial Dyslipidemias

Type Increased levels  Manifestation
1. Hyperchylomicronemia(type I hyperlipoproteinemia) Chylomicrons, TG and cholesterol Pancreatitis, hepatosplenomegaly, and xanthomas
2. Familial hypercholesterolemia(type II hyperlipoproteinemia) LDL and cholesterol Atherosclerosis and xanthomas
3. Dysbetalipoproteinemia(type III hyperlipoproteinemia) Chylomicrons and VLDL Atherosclerosis and xanthomas
4. Hypertriglyceridemia(type IV hyperlipoproteinemia) VLDL and TG Pancreatitis

questions.text:
A 34-year-old female presented with low Hb, platelet count of 25000/mm3, raised PT and aPTT. Peripheral smear findings are given below. Which of the following fusion genes is affected?

DIC-Disseminated intravascular coagulation
questions.solution:
The image showing numerous Auer rods and the lab findings pointing towards DIC are suggestive of acute myeloid leukaemia - M3 or acute promyelocytic leukaemia. The pathogenesis behind this is the PML-RARA fusion gene or translocation t(15,17).

AML-M3, or acute promyelocytic leukemia, is a subtype of acute myeloid leukemia associated with PML-RARɑ fusion gene or t(15;17). The patient presents with fever, fatigue, and weight loss. On examination, findings consistent with anemia (pallor) and thrombocytopenia (easy bruising) are seen. This is due to the accelerated destruction of RBC and platelet precursors in the bone marrow. 

Histopathology of the bone marrow aspirate reveals numerous Auer rods (needle-like azurophilic granules) in the cytoplasm of the promyelocytes. Sometimes, multiple Auer rods cluster together within a single cell resembling a bundle of sticks. Such cells have been termed faggot cells (faggot in French means bundle of sticks).

The condition is associated with a high incidence of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).

Treatment includes the administration of all-trans retinoic acid.

Other options:

Option A: CML is a myeloproliferative neoplasm. It is caused by BCR (on chromosome 22) - ABL (on chromosome 9) fusion gene translocation mutation. It results in the formation of the Philadelphia chromosome.

Option B: Multiple myeloma patients are affected by the translocation t(4;14) resulting in the IGH::NSD2 fusion.

Option C: AML with t(8:21) shows the RUNX1/RUNXT1 fusion gene.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is recently diagnosed and treated for familial adenomatous polyposis syndrome. He has a 9-year-old child. The family has been counseled and has agreed for the screening of the child. What is the initial step in screening the child?

choices.text: Genetic testing for APC gene mutation
Genetic testing for MSH-6 gene mutation
Routine flexible sigmoidoscopy starting from 10 years of age
Routine flexible colonoscopy starting from 20 years of age

questions.solution:
The initial step in screening the child for familial adenomatous polyposis syndrome is to perform genetic testing for APC gene mutation. If screening is positive, flexible sigmoidoscopy or colonoscopy is done annually starting from 10 years of age.

If the APC testing is negative, then the risk of developing colorectal carcinoma in the relative is similar to the general population. Hence the screening can be started from 50 years of age.

FAP is an autosomal dominant condition and is caused due to a mutation in the APC gene located on chromosome 5. Clinically, patients develop hundreds to thousands of adenomatous polyps in the colon and rectum. More than 100 colonic adenomas are diagnostic of FAP. Some patients may also develop duodenal adenomas. The lifetime risk of developing colorectal carcinoma in these patients is 100%. 

The extracolonic manifestations of FAP are:

  • Endodermal drerivatives
    • Adenomas and carcinomas of the stomach, duodenum, small intestine, thyroid, and biliary tree
    • Fundic gland polyps
    • Hepatoblastoma
  • Ectodermal derivatives
    • Epidermoid cyst
    • Pilomatrixoma
    • Congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium
    • Brain tumors
  • Mesodermal derivatives
    • Desmoid tumors
    • Osteomas
    • Dental problems

The treatment of the FAP includes total proctocolectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis (IPAA).

Variants of FAP are:

  • Gardner's syndrome- it is an autosomal dominant variant of FAP. In addition to colonic polyps, the patients will have
    • Osteomas of the mandible or skull
    • Epidermal cysts
    • Soft tissue tumors like desmoid tumor
  • Turcot's syndrome- in addition to the colonic polyps the patients will have central nervous system tumors (primary brain tumors).

Note: Hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC) syndrome, or Lynch syndrome occurs due to defects in DNA mismatch repair genes (MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, and PMS2)

Related Pearl: Features of Familial Adenomatous Polyposis

Gastrointestinal manifestations:

  • Colon and rectum: Multiple adenomatous polyp usually >100
  • Gastric and duodenal polyps are present in 50% cases.
  • Gastric polyp: fundal gland polyp, gastric adenoma.
  • Duodenal polyp usually in the ampullary region: Adenomatous and premalignant

Extraintestinal manifestations

  • Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE) seen in 75% of cases; it is detected by indirect ophthalmoscopy.
  • Epidermoid cysts
  • Desmoid tumors in the abdomen
  • Osteoma: In the skull, mandible, and tibia
  • Brain tumors
  • Tumors of the thyroid, adrenal, liver, pancreas, gallbladder, and bile duct

Related Pearl: Classification of colorectal polyps

Colorectal polyps can be classified as:

Neoplastic

Adenomatous polyps:

  • Tubular adenoma (Most common)
  • Tubulovillous adenomas
  • Villous adenoma (highest risk of malignancy)

Non-neoplastic:

  • Hyperplastic
  • Hamartomatous
    • Juvenile polyp(solitary)-benign
    • Juvenile polyposis syndromes (multiple)-premalignant
    • Peutz-Jeghers syndrome- occasionally carcinoma may develop.
    • Cronkite-Canada syndrome*
  • Inflammatory
    • Pseudopolyp
    • Benign lymphoid polyp

Note:

*Cronkite-Canada syndrome: Cancer occurs in the stomach, colon, and rectum, but it remains controversial whether these polyps  possess malignant potential. As many as 15% of patients with Cronkite- Canada syndrome have a malignant tumor at the time of diagnosis

questions.text: Mutation that leads to lung cancer in non smokers_________
questions.solution:
Lung cancer in non-smokers is more likely due to EGFR mutation.

Adenocarcinoma is the most common subtype in non-smokers and is associated with the loss of function of EGFR, ALK, ROS1, MET, or RET genes.

questions.text:
Type II MSUD results from the mutation in the genes encoding _____.

Maple syrup urine disease (MSUD)
questions.solution:
Type II maple syrup urine disease (MSUD) results from a mutation in the genes encoding dihydrolipoyl transacylase.

Maple Syrup Urine Disease is due to the impaired function of various components of the α ketoacid decarboxylase complex.

There are 4 known types of Maple Syrup Urine Disease:

  • Type IA and IB MSUD arise from mutations in the E1α and E1b gene, which encode the enzyme α-Ketoacid decarboxylase.
  • Type II arises from mutations in the E2 gene, which encodes dihydrolipoyl transacylase.
  • Type III arises from mutations in the E3 gene, which encodes dihydrolipoamide dehydrogenase.

questions.text:
A young woman in the casualty with right leg pain, swelling, and erythema is diagnosed with a DVT. She had a pulmonary embolism six months ago and was treated with warfarin, which was recently stopped. Coagulation assays show insensitivity to activated protein C. What is the likely finding upon further evaluation?

DVT: Deep Vein Thrombosis
questions.solution:
The patient’s presentation of DVT and history of pulmonary embolism, along with insensitivity to activated protein C, strongly suggests a Factor V Leiden mutation.

The mutation occurs in the Factor V gene and leads to the production of a Factor V protein that is resistant to inactivation by activated protein C (APC). Normally, APC degrades Factor V to prevent excessive clotting, but in individuals with Factor V Leiden, this process is impaired, leading to a higher risk of forming abnormal blood clots.

Factor V Leiden mutation is the most common inherited thrombophilia, which follows an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern. Heterozygous carriers have a 3 to 8 times increased risk of venous thromboembolism (VTE), while homozygous individuals have a significantly higher risk, approximately 50 to 100 times greater.

Patients with Factor V Leiden are at increased risk for conditions like deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE). The risk is further elevated in situations such as pregnancy, oral contraceptive use, and prolonged immobilization.

The diagnosis is typically confirmed through genetic testing for the Factor V Leiden mutation. Coagulation assays showing APC resistance are also indicative of this condition.

Management of patients with Factor V Leiden involves anticoagulation therapy during episodes of thrombosis. Long-term anticoagulation may be considered in patients with recurrent thrombotic events or significant risk factors. Preventive measures are crucial for high-risk situations to reduce the likelihood of thromboembolic events.

Other options:

Option A: While elevated homocysteine can increase the risk of thrombosis, it does not cause APC resistance.

Option C: The prothrombin gene mutation (G20210A) increases prothrombin levels, leading to a higher risk of clotting, but it does not involve APC resistance.

Option D: This condition leads to reduced inhibition of thrombin and other clotting factors, increasing clotting risk, but it is not associated with APC resistance.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy complains of bony pain and swelling in his left upper arm for 3 months. On plain X-ray, the following findings were seen. What is the most likely gene mutation involved in this disease?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the X-ray findings of sunray appearance are suggestive of osteosarcoma.  The most likely gene mutation is p53 mutation.

p53 and RB gene mutations are involved in osteosarcoma and sporadic cases have also been associated with mutations in the CHEK2 gene.

RAS, APC, PTEN gene mutations do not have a strong association with osteosarcoma.

Osteosarcoma is a primary malignant bone tumor, osteosarcoma has a bimodal age distribution, in adolescence (10–14 years) and again in the seventh decade. Osteosarcoma typically metaphyseal or metadiaphyseal, the majority present at the distal femur, proximal tibia, proximal femur, and humerus
Radiological features of osteosarcoma:

  • Irregular destruction in the metaphysis overshadowed by the formation of new bone
  • Lifting of the periosteum due to the formation of new bone
  • Bone formation along the blood vessels within the tumor centrifugally gives rise to ‘sunburst appearance’ 
  • Other forms of periosteal reaction commonly seen are Codman’s triangle.

Limb salvage surgeries are preferred over amputation. Neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by surgical resection and adjuvant chemotherapy is the preferred treatment. The principal first-line chemotherapeutic agents used in osteosarcoma are doxorubicin, cisplatin, ifosfamide, and methotrexate.

The image shows sunray appearance seen in osteosarcoma.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with vague abdominal pain since the last 6 months. He also noticed spontaneously appearing and disappearing tender nodules (clots) under the skin, at different locations. His blood investigations reveal elevated serum levels of CEA and CA 19-9. Which of the following genetic mutations is the most frequently inactivated tumor suppressor gene associated with this pancreatic mass?
questions.solution:
The presence of abdominal pain, migratory thrombophlebitis, and elevated serum levels of tumour markers like CEA and CA 19-9 in an elderly man point to a diagnosis of pancreatic cancer with Trousseau syndrome. The CDKN2A gene present on chromosome 9p, is the most frequently inactivated tumour-suppressor gene in these tumours.

K-RAS is the most frequently altered oncogene associated mutation with pancreatic cancer.

Migratory thrombophlebitis, known as the Trousseau syndrome, occurs in about 10% of patients and is attributable to the elaboration of platelet-activating factors and procoagulants from the carcinoma or its necrotic products.

Molecular alterations in pancreatic carcinogenesis:

Pancreatic adenocarcinomas arise from well-defined non-invasive precursor lesions in small ducts referred to as pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PanIN).

  • The K-RAS gene (chromosome 12p) is the most frequently altered oncogene in pancreatic cancer. This oncogene is activated by the point mutation in 90% to 95% of pancreatic cancers.
  • The CDKN2A gene (chromosome 9p) is inactivated in 30% of pancreatic cancers, making it the most frequently inactivated tumour-suppressor gene in these tumours. This complex locus encodes two tumour-suppressor proteins:p16 /INK4a and ARF.
  • Inactivation of the TP53 tumour-suppressor gene (chromosome 17p) occurs in 70% to 75% of pancreatic cancers.
  • SMAD4 tumour-suppressor gene (chromosome 18q) is inactivated in 55% of pancreatic cancers.

Following genes are associated with an inherited predisposition to pancreatic cancer:

  • BRCA2 mutation: some pancreatic cancer, breast cancer, prostate cancer, and ovarian cancers.
  • PRSS1 mutation: Pancreatic carcinoma starting early in life secondary to hereditary pancreatitis.
  • SPINK1 is only associated with hereditary pancreatitis, but not pancreatic cancer.

Interesting fact: Armand Trousseau, the physician after whom Trosseau syndrome is named, correctly suspected that he had carcinoma when he developed spontaneously appearing and disappearing (migratory) thromboses.

questions.text: A child presents with hepatitis and progressive neurological degeneration. A slit-lamp examination of a patient showed the following picture. Which of the following is the molecular defect seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The image depicts the Kayser–Fleischer (KF) ring, which is seen in Wilson's disease. ATP7B is the molecular defect seen in this patient. 

Wilson's disease is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by loss of function mutation of the ATP7B gene, which codes for the enzyme copper-transporting ATPase present on the hepatocyte canalicular membrane.

In general, the free copper is taken up by hepatocytes and incorporated to form ceruloplasmin gets released into the bloodstream, and accounts for 90% to 95% of plasma copper. Excess hepatic copper gets transported into the bile and eventually excreted in the faeces.

The defect in the ATP7B gene impairs copper transport into the bile, its incorporation into ceruloplasmin, and secretion of ceruloplasmin into the blood. This results in a decrease in circulating ceruloplasmin levels (<20 mg/dL) and increased levels of hepatic copper. Total serum copper level may be decreased due to the deficiency in ceruloplasmin.

The excessive accumulation of copper injures the hepatocytes. This in turn releases the non-ceruloplasmin-bound copper into the bloodstream, which later gets deposited in tissues like the basal ganglia of the brain and the cornea. This results in behavioural disturbances as well as extrapyramidal symptoms and the characteristic KF ring that is seen on slit-lamp examination. There is a marked compensatory urinary copper excretion. However, these levels do not suffice to prevent the deposition of copper in tissues.

Clinical features of Wilson disease:

  • Hepatomegaly (with or without splenomegaly)
  • Acute/subacute/chronic hepatitis
  • Cirrhosis, ascites, portal hypertension
  • Tremor, dystonia, parkinsonism, behavioral, and psychiatric changes
  • Kayser-Fleischer ring
  • Coomb's negative hemolytic anemia (due to large amounts of copper released from damaged hepatocytes)
  • Renal Fanconi syndrome
  • Endocrinopathies

Important molecule defect and disease:

ATP7A (Option C) Menke’s disease 
ATP7B Wilson disease 
CFTR (Option A) Cystic fibrosis 
SERPINA 1  α-1 antitrypsin deficiency 
ABCC2 (MRP2 protein defect- Option B) Dubin Johnson syndrome

questions.text: A neurodegenerative disease causing UMN as well as LMN weakness, affecting the green areas on the spinal cord is shown in the image. Which of the following gene mutation is responsible for the disease?
questions.solution:
The given image and clinical scenario is of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis, which is caused due to SOD 1 gene mutation. The image has the anterior horn of the spinal cord and the corticospinal tracts highlighted in green, representing the areas of the spinal cord affected by amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).

The pathologic hallmark of ALS is the death of the affected lower motor neurons (LMN) consisting of the anterior horn cells of the spinal cord and their homologs in the brainstem, upper motor neurons (UMN) consisting of the corticospinal tract and corticobulbar tract originating in the motor cortex. The hereditary forms of ALS have mutations in the genes encoding for superoxide dismutase (SOD 1) present on chromosome 21.

Patients with ALS present with insidious onset asymmetric bilateral weakness of the distal part of the lower limbs. There may be a history of cramping, particularly early in the morning. Lower motor neuron death causes muscle atrophy and fasciculations. Upper motor neuron involvement presents as exaggerated tendon reflexes and spasticity.

The involvement of the corticobulbar fibers leads to exaggerated expressions of emotion, such as excessive weeping or laughing. This is called the pseudobulbar affect. Some patients also tend to develop frontotemporal dementia. However, sensory, bowel, and bladder functions and cognition are preserved, even in the late stages of the disease.

Other options:

Option A: SMN1 mutation- Spinal muscular atrophy: The SMN1 (Survival Motor Neuron 1) gene produces a protein crucial for motor neuron survival. Mutations in this gene result in spinal muscular atrophy (SMA), a genetic disorder characterized by progressive muscle weakness and atrophy due to loss of motor neurons in the spinal cord.

Option C: APP mutation- Alzheimer's disease: The APP (Amyloid Precursor Protein) gene is associated with Alzheimer’s disease. Mutations in this gene can lead to the abnormal accumulation of beta-amyloid plaques in the brain, which are hallmarks of Alzheimer’s and contribute to neurodegeneration and cognitive decline.

Option D: ATM mutation- Cancer protection gene: The ATM (Ataxia-Telangiectasia Mutated) gene plays a role in DNA repair and cellular response to damage. Mutations in this gene are linked to ataxia-telangiectasia, a condition with increased cancer risk.

questions.text: What is the most common genetic alteration of this thyroid tumor?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the presence of empty nuclei, also called Orphan Annie eye nuclei which is characteristic of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid. The most common is the BRAF V600E mutation.

BRAF V600E mutation is also seen in

  • Langerhans cell histiocytosis
  • Hairy cell leukemia
  • Colon adenocarcinoma
  • Melanoma

Other chromosomal rearrangements in papillary thyroid carcinoma:

  • RET-PTC fusion (option A) - seen in sporadic papillary cancers; uncommon
  • NTRK1 mutation

Microscopic features of papillary thyroid carcinoma include:

  • Branching papillae with fibrovascular stalk
  • Covering epithelium is simple or stratified cuboidal
  • Orphan Annie eye nuclei -  
    • Empty-appearing nuclei due to dispersed chromatin
    • They are diagnostic, regardless of papillary architecture
  • Psammoma bodies - concentric calcified structures
  • Foci of lymphatic invasion 


Other options:

Option C: p53 mutation is seen in anaplastic thyroid cancer. 

Option D: RAS mutation is seen in follicular thyroid cancer.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old male patient was referred to you with features of pituitary adenoma and testicular tumor. While going through his radiological reports, you saw the presence of parathyroid adenoma, and his chromosomal studies show a mutation in the CDKN1B gene. What is the most likely diagnosis?

CDKN1B gene : Cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor 1b gene
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of pituitary adenoma, parathyroid adenoma, testicular tumor, and a mutation in the CDKN1B gene is suggestive of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 4 (MEN 4).

MEN 4 is an autosomal dominant endocrine tumor syndrome. It occurs due to the germline mutation in the CDKN1B gene in chromosome 12.

MEN 4 often presents with parathyroid adenoma, pituitary adenoma, reproductive organ tumors like testicular cancer, or neuroendocrine cervical cancer with adrenal or renal tumors. 

The clinical presentation in MEN 4 is almost similar to MEN1. The difference between MEN1 and MEN4 is in the germline mutation, where MEN 1 occurs due to the mutation of the MEN1 gene.

Multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) is a group of autosomal dominant disorders characterized by tumors involving two or more endocrine glands. Depending on the chromosomal location of germline mutation they are divided into four major forms as MEN 1, MEN 2A, MEN 2B (MEN 3), and MEN 4. MEN 1 is the most common among the four types. 

Other Options:

Option B- MEN 3 is also known as MEN 2B. It occurs due to a mutation of the RET gene. It is associated with medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, mucosal neuroma, marfanoid features. In contrast with MEN2A, parathyroid hyperplasia is not seen in MEN 2B.

Option C- MEN 2A is also known as Sipple's syndrome. It occurs due to a mutation of the RET gene. It is associated with medullary carcinoma thyroid, pheochromocytoma, and parathyroid adenoma.

Option D- MEN 1 is also known as Wermer's syndrome. It occurs due to a mutation in the MEN 1 gene. It is associated with parathyroid adenoma, pancreatic tumors, and pituitary tumors. 

Related Pearl: MEN 1 Syndrome Features

Chromosome 11q13 / MEN1 gene

Also known as Wermer’s syndrome

Characteristic tumors seen in:

  • Parathyroid adenoma – 90 % - Most common overall
  • Entero pancreatic tumors - Most common functioning tumor is gastrinoma (most common site is duodenum)
  • Pituitary adenoma – Most common is prolactinoma
  • Mnemonic – Par Pan Pit – in decreasing order of frequency

Associated tumors are:

  • Angiofibroma
  • Collagenomas
  • Adrenal cortical tumors
  • Lipoma
  • Neuroendocrine tumors - gastric, thymic, lungs
  • Meningioma
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Carcinoid tumors, usually of the foregut

Related Pearl: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

  • Known as Sipple’s syndrome
  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

  • Known commonly as MEN 3
  • Chromosome 10/ RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Other associated abnormalities include: (40–50%)
      • Mucosal neuromas
      • Marfanoid habitus
      • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
      • Megacolon

Related Pearl: MEN 4 Syndrome Features

It is associated with CDKN1B gene on chromosome 12.

Associated conditions:

  • Parathyroid adenoma
  • Pituitary adenoma
  • Reproductive organ tumors like testicular cancer, neuroendocrine cervical carcinoma
  • Adrenal and renal tumors

questions.text:
A couple comes to a hospital for genetic counselling and upon further evaluation, the husband is found to have Marfan syndrome. The inheritance pattern and mutation associated with this condition are:

FBN 1- Fibrillin 1 gene

FBN 2- Fibrillin 2 gene

choices.text: Autosomal dominant, mutation in FBN-1 gene
Autosomal recessive, mutation in FBN-1 gene
Autosomal dominant, mutation in FBN-2 gene
Autosomal recessive, mutation in FBN-2 gene

questions.solution:
The inheritance pattern and the mutation in Marfan syndrome are that it is autosomal dominant and is associated with a mutation in FBN-1 gene.

Marfan syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder affecting connective tissues associated chiefly with cardiovascular, ocular, and musculoskeletal abnormalities, although involvement of other organ systems like the central nervous system, respiratory system and skin has also been observed. It results from an inherited defect in an extracellular glycoprotein called Fibrillin-1.

Fibrillin occurs in two homologous forms, fibrillin-1 and fibrillin-2, encoded by two separate genes, FBN-1 and FBN-2, located on long arms of chromosomes 15 and 5, respectively. Mutations of FBN-1 give rise to Marfan syndrome while mutations of the related FBN2 gene give rise to congenital contractural arachnodactyly, an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by skeletal abnormalities, which is less common. 

Fibrillin-1 is a regulator of TGF-β which is responsible for inflammation, fibrosis, and activation of specific matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs), particularly MMP-2 and MMP-9.

Patients with Marfan syndrome are tall and have an decreased upper to lower segment ratio with long arms, hands, and fingers. Deformities of the chest wall, vertebral column, and foot arches may be present.

Associated cardiovascular abnormalities include mitral valve prolapse leading to mitral regurgitation and dilatation of aortic root/sinuses of Valsalva leading to aortic regurgitation, aortic dissection, and rupture.

Ocular Features include ectopia lentis, cataract, refractive errors like myopia due to increased axial length and retinal detachment

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy has been observed by his parents to be increasingly clumsy for the past 6 months. On physical examination, there is a cauliflower-like growth in the left eye along with leukocoria and an absent red reflex. The microscopic appearance of the specimen shows Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes. Which is the causative gene in the given condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical history and histology point toward a diagnosis of retinoblastoma which occurs due to a mutation in the Rb gene located on chromosome 13q14.

Retinoblastoma is the most common intraocular malignancy in children. White pupillary reflex or leukocoria is the most common presenting feature, followed by a squint which is usually convergent. Rarely, the child may present with nystagmus and defective vision.

Clinical features of retinoblastoma:

  • Present within the first two years of life
  • Leukocoria 
  • Strabismus
  • Painful red eye with secondary glaucoma
  • Orbital inflammation mimicking orbital or pre-septal cellulitis.
  • Orbital invasion or visible extraocular growth may occur in neglected cases.
  • Metastatic disease involving regional lymph nodes and the brain before the detection of ocular involvement is rare.

Signs:

  • An intraretinal tumor is a homogeneous, dome-shaped white lesion that becomes irregular, often with white flecks of calcification.
  • An endophytic tumor projects into the vitreous as a white mass that may "seed" into the gel.
  • An exophytic tumor forms multilobular subretinal white masses and causes an overlying retinal detachment.

Investigations:

  • Red reflex testing with a direct ophthalmoscope is a simple screening test for leukocoria.
  • Dilated fundus examination using indirect ophthalmoscope
  • MRI of the orbit + brain is the investigation of choice.

 The HPE image below shows Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes, the clustering of small blue cuboidal or short columnar cells around a central lumen.

Treatment typically involves chemotherapy plus focal therapy. The commonly used three-drug regimen is the CVE regimen consisting of vincristine, carboplatin, and etoposide. Focal therapy includes cryotherapy, laser photocoagulation, thermotherapy, plaque radiotherapy, and external beam radiotherapy. Enucleation is done when: 

  • Tumor involves more than half of the retina
  • Optic nerve is involved
  • Glaucoma is present and the anterior chamber is involved

In the stage of extraocular extension, the globe bursts through the sclera, usually near the limbus or the optic disc. This is followed by rapid fungation and involvement of extraocular tissues resulting in marked proptosis. Distant metastasis occurs through the lymphatic spread and the direct extension by continuity to the optic nerve and brain.

Other options:

Option B: COL5A1 mutation affects type 5 collagen. This mutation is seen in Ehlers-Danlos syndrome.

Option C: Retinitis pigmentosa occurs due to inherited or acquired mutations in the rhodopsin gene. 

Option D: NOTCH1 is the most commonly affected gene in T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (T-ALL).

questions.text: An elderly female patient presented with complaints of abdominal pain, weight loss, and early satiety for 2 years. Endoscopy was suggestive of gastric cancer. A biopsy of the same is shown below. Which of the following molecular pathophysiological features may be seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The image showing signet ring cells is suggestive of diffuse-type gastric cancer, which has decreased E-cadherin expression. Cells in diffuse-type gastric cancer have large mucin vacuoles that expand the cytoplasm and push the nucleus to the periphery, which creates a signet-ring cell.

Lauren's system classifies gastric cancer into the following types based on differences in etiology, epidemiology, and pathology:

  • Type I - intestinal
  • Type II - diffuse

Molecular pathologies seen in the intestinal type are as follows:

  • Loss-of-function mutations in the APC gene or in β-catenin
  • Inactivation of p53 (tumor-suppressor gene) and p16 (cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor)
  • Microsatellite instability

Molecular pathologies seen in diffuse-type are as follows: 

  • Loss-of-function mutations in CDH1, leading to decreased E-cadherin
  • Inactivation of p53 and p16

questions.text: A 52-year-old male presenting with abdominal pain and melena is diagnosed with a Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumor (GIST) following an upper GI endoscopy. Which mutation is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical condition is diagnosed as gastrointestinal stromal tumour(GIST) and it occurs due to gain-of-function mutations in receptor tyrosine kinase KIT (~75%)

GIST is the most common mesenchymal tumour of the abdomen, with the most common site being the stomach(50%). However, it can arise from any part of the git. The tumour arises from the interstitial cells of Cajal or pacemaker cells of the gastrointestinal muscularis propria.

Most GISTs occur due to gain-of-function mutations in receptor tyrosine kinase KIT (~75%) or PDGRF-ɑ (~8%). 

The tumour peaks at 60 years of age. It is often associated with the Carney triad, a nonhereditary condition characterized by GIST, paraganglioma, and pulmonary chondroma. GIST also has a higher incidence in individuals with neurofibromatosis I.

Patients typically present with anaemia (blood loss caused by mucosal ulceration) and symptoms of mass effect. However, GISTs may also be discovered incidentally during imaging or surgery.

Microscopically, GIST can be of two patterns:

  1. Spindle cell type: The tumour is composed of thin elongated cells.
  2. Epitheloid type: The tumour is composed of plump epithelial-like cells.

Mixed patterns may also be seen.

The most useful immunohistochemical marker is KIT (CD117) detectable in Cajal cells.

The prognosis depends on tumour size, mitotic index, and location (GISTs arising in the stomach are less aggressive than those arising in the small intestine). Complete surgical resection is the mainstay treatment. For unresectable, recurrent, or metastatic GISTs, imatinib, a tyrosine kinase inhibitor, can be used. 

Other options:

Option B: KRAS is an oncogene that encodes a GTPase protein involved in the RAS/MAPK signalling pathway, regulating cell growth and proliferation. Mutations in KRAS are commonly associated with cancers like colorectal, lung, and pancreatic cancers.

Option C: The PHEX gene (phosphate-regulating endopeptidase on X chromosome) is associated with X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets. Mutation of PHEX leads to increased phosphatonin (FGF 23) levels, and hence, the excretion of phosphorous is increased.

Option D: Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is a glycoprotein produced primarily by the fetal liver and yolk sac, serving as a marker for fetal development. Elevated AFP levels in adults are associated with conditions like hepatocellular carcinoma and germ cell tumours.

Related Pearl: Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumor (GIST)

M/C mesenchymal tumor of GIT arising from interstitial cells of Cajal (pacemaker cells of GIT). Stomach is the m/c site.

GISTs express:

  • c-KIT (CD117)
  • PDGF receptor A
  • CD34
  • SDH

Clinical Features:

  • Peaks at 60 years of age.
  • M/C symptom: Upper GI bleeding
  • Other symptoms: Pain, lump, perforation, incidental finding
  • Carney's Triad: Sporadic GIST, Paraganglioma, Pulmonary chondroma

Management:

  • IOC for primary GIST: CECT abdomen
  • IOC for recurrent GIST: PET-CT
  • IHC markers: CD117/C-KIT (M/C), DOG 1 (most specific), CD 34
  • Route of metastasis: Hematogenous

The following image shows microscopy of GIST composed of spindle-shaped tumor cells:

  • Fletcher's classification (Tumor size & No. of mitotic figures) is used to classify the tumors according to their malignancy risk.
  • Prognosis is determined by: Mitotic index, tumor size & location of tumor (Stomach GISTs are less aggressive).
  • Complete surgical resection is the mainstay treatment. For unresectable, recurrent, or metastatic GISTs, imatinib, a tyrosine kinase inhibitor, can be used.

questions.text: A 50-year-old postmenopausal woman presented to the clinic with a history of a lump in her right breast for six months. Radiological examination showed an irregular spiculated lesion of 8 mm with microcalcification. A biopsy was taken, and the immunohistochemistry results revealed that the cell membrane was stained brown. Identify the pathophysiological mechanism of the underlying condition.

choices.text: Point mutation of JAK2 receptor gene
Point mutation of EGFR tyrosine kinase

questions.solution:
The mechanism of neoplasia(underlying condition) here is due to the amplification of the ERBB2 gene, resulting in abnormal HER2neu receptors.

The given clinical stem is suggestive of invasive breast carcinoma. The radiological imaging with irregular, spiculated margins and microcalcifications is an indication for biopsy for further assessment. In the immunohistochemistry studies, the cell membrane is stained brown, indicating a HER2neu-positive tumour. Fluorescent in situ hybridisation (FISH) can be used adjunctively to confirm the diagnosis. HER2-positive is the second most common molecular subtype of invasive breast cancer.

HER2 receptors (also known as ERBB2) is a receptor tyrosine kinase that promotes cell proliferation and opposes apoptosis by stimulating the RAS- and PI3K-AKT signalling pathways. 

Immunohistochemistry staining of breast carcinoma - 

  • The Estrogen receptor (ER) and Progesterone receptor (PR) are nuclear receptors, and the nucleus is stained brown.
  • The human epidermal growth factor receptor type 2 (HER2) is a membrane receptor. Hence, the cell membrane is stained brown if positive.

The image below shows positive and negative staining for ER, PR, and HER2.

Other options:-

Option B: Point mutation of the JAK2 receptor gene is seen in myeloproliferative neoplasias. 

Option C: EGFR belongs to the ERBB1 family of transmembrane receptor tyrosine kinase. EGFR is essential for the growth and differentiation of epithelial cells. Point mutation of this is the causative mechanism for adenocarcinoma of the lung. 

Option D: Gene amplification of the n-myc gene is seen in neuroblastoma.

questions.text: A 3-month-old baby boy presents with recurrent bacterial infections, and a history of bloody diarrhoea and eczema since the first month of life. Peripheral smear shows small-sized platelets. Which gene is defective in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests Wiskott–Aldrich syndrome and the defective gene is the WASP gene.

Wiskott–Aldrich syndrome is an X-linked recessive disease characterized by thrombocytopenia and small-sized platelets. Patients often present in infancy with bruising, bloody diarrhoea, eczema, and susceptibility to recurrent infections. It occurs due to mutations in the gene located at Xp11.23 that encodes the Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome protein (WASP).

Along with microthrombocytopenia, peripheral smear shows loss of T lymphocytes. Patients can also not produce antibodies to antigens, thereby making them immunocompromised. As a result, there is also an increased risk of autoimmune disorders and cancers like B-cell lymphomas.

Splenectomy improves platelet counts in these patients since increased platelet destruction in the spleen is prevented. However, the only definitive treatment is hematopoietic stem cell transplantation.

Other options:

Option A: The Bruton tyrosine kinase (BTK) gene is mutated in X-linked agammaglobulinemia. It occurs because the B-cells fail to undergo maturation. All lines of immunoglobulins are found to be low in this disease. Since it is an X-linked disorder, it is most commonly seen in young males. They present after the age of 6 months with recurrent respiratory tract infections.

Option B:  BAFF gene mutation leads to common variable immunodeficiency. Patients usually have persistent diarrhoea caused by G. lamblia, recurring sinopulmonary pyogenic infections, and potentially serious enterovirus infections that cause meningoencephalitis. Symptoms appear later in childhood or adolescence than in X-linked agammaglobulinemia.

Option C: Ataxia telangiectasia is caused due to mutation of the ATM gene. This gene is involved in the repair of double-strand DNA breaks. This defect in DNA repair leads to impaired Ig isotype switching and the formation of antigen receptors. As a result, the patient is immunodeficient with partial T cell deficiency, and hence live vaccines are avoided. 

Related Pearl: Causes of Thrombocytopenia

I. Decreased Production of Platelets

  1. Selective impairment of platelet production
    • Drug-induced: alcohol, thiazides, cytotoxic drugs
    • Infections: measles, human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)
  2. Nutritional deficiencies - megaloblastic leukemia
  3. Bone marrow failure - aplastic anemia
  4. Bone marrow replacement - leukemia, disseminated cancer, granulomatous disease
  5. Ineffective hematopoiesis - myelodysplastic syndromes 

II. Decreased Platelet Survival

  1. Immunologic destruction
    • Primary autoimmune - chronic immune thrombocytopenic purpura, acute immune thrombocytopenic purpura
    • Secondary autoimmune - systemic lupus erythematosus, B-cell lymphoid neoplasms
    • Alloimmune: posttransfusion and neonatal
    • Drug-associated: quinidine, heparin, sulfa compounds
    • Infections: HIV, infectious mononucleosis (transient, mild), dengue fever
  2. Nonimmunologic destruction
    • Disseminated intravascular coagulation
    • Thrombotic microangiopathies
    • Giant hemangiomas

III. Sequestration - Hypersplenism

IV. Dilution - Transfusions

questions.text: A 45-year-old man has the following lesion over the face. The patient is apprehensive about history of brain tumors and similar skin pathologies in the family. On examination he had scoliosis and Chest X ray  revealed bifid ribs. Which of the following  gene mutation can be expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given family histories brain tumours, with the image showing an ulcer over the face with pearly, rolled-out borders suggestive basal cell carcinoma and association of bifid ribs and vertebral anomalies likely points to the diagnosis of Gorlin syndrome. Mutation of PTCH gene is seen in this condition.

Gorlin syndrome also known as nevoid basal cell carcinoma  syndrome is an autosomal dominant condition caused by mutations in the PTCH gene which codes for PATCHED protiens. In the absence of PATCHED proteins, there is unopposed Hedgehog signaling that increases the expression of a number of pro-growth genes. It is associated with a high risk of basal cell carcinoma and medulloblastoma.

Other features that can be seen associated are:

  • Highly characteristic facies (with large forehead)
  • Bifid or misshapen ribs
  • Vertebral and other skeletal anomalies (Scoliosis)
  • Pits of the skin of the palms and soles
  • Dysgenesis of the corpus callosum
  • Calcification of the falx cerebri (at an earlier age than is seen in non‐affected individuals)

Other options: 

Option A: Cowden syndrome/ Multiple hamartoma syndrome is an autosomal dominant condition caused by mutations in PTEN gene. It is associated with hamartomas of all three embryonal cell layers and dysplastic gangliogliocytoma of the cerebellum. Most common harmartomas include facial trichilemmomas.

Option B: VHL gene  mutation is seen in von Hippel–Lindau syndrome which is associated with cerebellar hemangioblastoma, retinal angioma, renal cell carcinoma, pheochromocytoma and cystic lesions of kidneys, pancreas, liver, and inner ear (endolymphatic sac tumors).

Option C: Turcot syndrome is caused by mutations in APC gene or mismatch repair genes and is associated with intestinal polyposis and multiple CNS tumors like Medulloblastoma or glioblastoma.
